justification: The reduction of GHG emissions in the agriculture sector can lead to increased costs for farmers and food producers, potentially impacting food prices and affordability.
The transition to a low-carbon economy may require significant investments in new technologies and practices, potentially affecting the competitiveness of the agriculture sector.
Reducing GHG emissions can lead to a decrease in synthetic fertilizer use, which in turn can reduce the need for pesticides and promote more sustainable agricultural practices.
Carbon removal technologies, such as afforestation and soil carbon sequestration, can improve soil health and fertility, leading to better crop yields and higher quality food.
Improving energy efficiency in buildings can lead to a reduction in energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions, creating a healthier indoor environment and promoting sustainable food systems.
The transition to low-emission transportation can lead to increased costs for the transportation of food products, potentially impacting food prices and affordability.
Enhancing climate resilience can help protect agricultural systems from the impacts of climate change, ensuring a stable food supply and promoting food quality.

Reducing GHG emissions in the agriculture sector can lead to improved animal welfare, as more sustainable farming practices are often associated with better treatment and living conditions for animals.
